reviewText: Bought this to try unusual movies. And to see Dack Rambo in something other than Murder She Wrote or Guns of Will Sonnet. However, this had no plot. Was choppy & lacked any humor. And the actor who is the voice of Classic Tigger as a Nazi is most unsettling!

reviewText: I was surprised to notice that this DVD was a DVD-ROM containing "Which Way to the Front?", without any menus or subtitles whatsoever. There are 10 chapters in the main feature but the user has to reach them by the Skip buttons on the remote. The movie is contained in a single layer disc, but the picture quality is subpar. It can be played with reasonable quality with an upscaling player.
summary: Bare-bones edition, only for those who really like this movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It was common back during Jerry Lewis' solo filmmaking days to trash his efforts more than admitting that they were actually quite good. 1970's "Which Way to the Front" falls in this category. Set during 1943 WW II, Lewis plays (more maturely than usual; he even sports a goattee) multi-millionaire Brendan Byers, who's done it all, and now wants to serve his country...then gets rejected by the army. The line "It's every man's right to die fighting for his country" works smirkingly well in connecting with the then-Vietnam anti-war sentiment. Byers' solution? Create his own army through financing (and recruiting a handful of fellow 4-Fs). What follows is a funny string of gags & jokes as Byers & his troop go into combat training (rafting in the mansion pool; parachuting off a mechanical lift, etc.). Note: This is basically a satire on war films, although Lewis comforts his audience who would like to see a typical Lewis comedy (his reliable shtick of comically reacting to the word "reject" is particularly hilarious).There's many familiar faces throughout: longtime foil Kathleen Freeman, Fritz Feld, Joe Besser, etc. And Lewis' 4-Fs---Jan Murray, Steve Franken, Dack Rambo, John Wood, etc.---memorably round out the cast. Lewis' bunker scene with Hitler (played with scenery-chewing glee by Sidney Miller) is undoubtedly the highlight of the film.Is WWTTF subtle? Hardly. Let's face it: Some viewers may be put off, as the proceedings get quite loud & over the top. But hey, this is Jerry Lewis we're talking about! His stock-in-trade is pure comic disruption. And really, does anyone remember TV's "Hogan's Heroes"? The "Springtime for Hitler" number in Mel Brooks' "The Producers"? They were unapologetically UN-subtle, and drove home the point that Hitler & the Nazis deserved to be made fun of.It's just a shame that Warner Brothers (then) had little faith in adequately promoting this Lewis comedy, for it could've given him the clout to create films into the 70's.Arguably, his funniest comedy since "The Big Mouth"!
summary: Lewis' satirical war comedy before calling it quits
Title: N/A

reviewText: Finally available on DVD, the erratic "Which Way to the Front?" (1970) has a few classic sequences featuring Jerry Lewis in top form. After a slow start, the World War II farce improves when Jerry impersonates a Nazi officer - highlighted by his brilliant Chaplinesque ballet with Adolf Hitler. Though a major hit in Europe, this Lewis effort was barely shown in America. Opening credits begin near the 20-minute mark - a rarity in cinema history. The Warner Archive release has an excellent widescreen transfer, but no extras.OVERALL RATING: **
summary: Uneven Lewis Comedy Gets Widescreen Treatment
Title: N/A

reviewText: Which Way To The Front? (1970), an outrageous farce set in Italy during World War II, marked the end of Jerry Lewis' long career starring in feature films.  With a wartime setting, an ensemble cast, and no women in significant roles, the film was quite a departure from the typical Lewis vehicle.  Lewis also served as director and executive producer.  The story by Gerald Gardner and Dee Caruso, writing partners onThe MonkeesTV show, starts out well enough, but goes way over the top, once the action shifts to Italy.Jerry Lewis built his career playing variations of the good-hearted, but accident prone goof, and continued to do so well into his 40's.  As he got older, Lewis played more sophisticated and mature characters, but the "old Jerry" would still occasionally appear.  There's a bit of that here, as Lewis assumes dual roles, playing Brendan Byers III, an American businessman worth millions, who just happens to be the spitting image of Field Marshall Kesselring, the officer in command of Germany's forces in Italy.When Byers is drafted and found to be unsuitable for military service, he decides to form a private attack force to oppose Hitler.  He recruits other 4-F rejects, and members of his household staff, and after undergoing training, heads over to Italy, on his private yacht.  With the war in Italy at a stalemate, Byers' plan is to impersonate Field Marshall Kesselring, and order a retreat of the German forces.  Traveling through enemy territory, the group arrives at Kesselring's castle headquarters, and somehow affect the switch, as Byers replaces Kesselring, and his commandos become members of the German army.There are a number of amusing adventures in the castle, as Kesselring presents soldiers with medals, and has an encounter with the mayor's wife (Kaye Ballard).  As the phony Kesselring, Byers orders the German forces to withdraw, but fearing a trap, the Allies fail to advance.  The insanity reaches a fever pitch, when it is revealed that Kesselring is involved in a plot to kill Hitler, and then visits the Fuher in a secret bunker.  In what is perhaps one of the most outrageous depictions of Adolph Hitler, Sidney Miller plays him as a weepy sentimental sniveler, who has a "special" relationship with Kesselring.  It's quite bizarre, as after rewriting history, Byers and his men next look to wrap up the war in the Pacific.While Lewis clearly is the star, the supporting cast, which includes Jan Murray, Paul Winchell, John Wood, Steve Franken, Willie Davis, and Harold J. Stone, are featured more prominently, than usual for a Lewis film.  Kaye Ballard, is the only female with a significant role, while George "Sulu" Takei, makes a brief appearance as a sword wielding gardener.Like most of Lewis' films, this one is largely a series of gags.  When a segment is done, rather than cutting to the next scene, the action is freeze framed.  Even for Lewis, this is pretty lazy filmmaking.  Other featured Lewis trademarks are goofy voices, quirky movements, disguises, ethnic stereotypes, and jokes taken to ridiculous extremes.  Jerry's concept of humor was well established, and Caruso and Gardner appear to have adapted to his style pretty well, with some outrageous results.Hogan's Heroeswas slammed by some critics, but that program had some sense of tension and danger, because the Germans were actually trying to win the war.  In Which Way to the Front?, little is taken seriously, Hitler is a dainty sensitive type, and the German soldiers are idiots.  Making a complete mockery of WWII, it's not a very sophisticated approach, but then subtlety was not what Jerry Lewis was about.Die hard Lewis fans will probably appreciate this 3.5 star film, it has plenty of Jerry's shtick, but compared to some of his earlier efforts, it does have a certain amount of "sophistication".  Jerry shares the stage to some extent, as John Wood and Jan Murray each have some good moments, and Paul Winchell, who perhaps could have done a better job of playing Hitler than Sidney Miller, brings a lot of enthusiasm to working with Jerry.Typical for a Warner Archive DVD-R release, there are no subtitles, or bonus materials.  The presentation is in anamorphic widescreen, image quality is very good, and the film's rousing soundtrack sounds great.
summary: monkees writers collaborate with jerry lewis in his last major feature film...
